body_html:
This is odd. Can you show the contents of the pip.log? I am using OS X Sierra, but pip install works fine, maybe it is only on Linux? I will try to run it on Ubuntu tomorrow, if no solution is found by then.

Here is my run sequence:

$> mkvirtualenv dev-test
(dev-test) $> wget https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/mac/cpu/protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_11_x86_64.whl
protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-none- 100%[===================================>]   4.58M  2.33MB/s    in 2.0s
(dev-test) $> pip install --upgrade protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_11_x86_64.whl
Processing ./protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_11_x86_64.whl
Requirement already up-to-date: setuptools in /Users/zafar/.virtualenvs/dev-test/lib/python2.7/site-packages (from protobuf==3.0.0)
Collecting six>=1.9 (from protobuf==3.0.0)
  Downloading six-1.10.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: six, protobuf
Successfully installed protobuf-3.0.0 six-1.10.0

EDIT:
OK, according to the SO, you might have problems with your .pypirc. The possible solutions are in the formentioned SO post. Also, try --index.

According to the Google search results, it might be happening because you are using HTTP and not HTTPS

body:
This is odd. Can you show the contents of the `pip.log`? I am using OS X Sierra, but `pip install` works fine, maybe it is only on Linux? I will try to run it on Ubuntu tomorrow, if no solution is found by then.

Here is my run sequence:

``` bash
$> mkvirtualenv dev-test
(dev-test) $> wget https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/mac/cpu/protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_11_x86_64.whl
protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-none- 100%[===================================>]   4.58M  2.33MB/s    in 2.0s
(dev-test) $> pip install --upgrade protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_11_x86_64.whl
Processing ./protobuf-3.0.0-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_11_x86_64.whl
Requirement already up-to-date: setuptools in /Users/zafar/.virtualenvs/dev-test/lib/python2.7/site-packages (from protobuf==3.0.0)
Collecting six>=1.9 (from protobuf==3.0.0)
  Downloading six-1.10.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: six, protobuf
Successfully installed protobuf-3.0.0 six-1.10.0
```

EDIT:
OK, according to the [SO](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24101300/pip-could-not-find-any-downloads-that-satisfy-the-requirement-sqlalchemy), you might have problems with your `.pypirc`. The possible solutions are in the formentioned SO post. Also, try [`--index`](http://pip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/pip_wheel/#index-url).

According to the Google search results, it might be happening because you are using `HTTP` and not `HTTPS`
